title: Numbers and Counting
content:
When learning any new language, it seems one of the early staples is learning to count. This can obviously help with communication and understanding in it's most basic form.

As this is a completely new concept for me, I'll stick with memorizing 1-10 first and then continue to add as I remember.

Here is the first reference:


#
Russian
English
1
ОдинOne
2
ДваTwo
3
ТриThree
4
ЧетыреFour
5
ПятьFive
6
ШестьSix
7
СемьSeven
8
ВосемьEight
9
ДевятьNine
10
ДесятьTen

One of the more difficult pieces I've encountered in Russian is how numbers change depending on the context. For instance 'Один' is what you'll find in most Russian learning resources.

title: Cryllic Alphabet
content:
One of the more common themes I saw when doing some preliminary research was to try and avoid 'transliteration.'

transliteration - the process of transferring a word from the alphabet of one language to another. This helps people pronounce words and names in foreign languages.

One of the first things I'll begin to study is the actual Cryllic Alphabet:


А аБ бВ вГ гД дЕ е
Ё ёЖ жЗ зИ иЙ йК к
Л лМ мН нО оП пР р
С сТ тУ уФ фХ хЦ ц
Ч чШ шЩ щЪ ъЫ ыЬ ь
Э эЮ юЯ я

title: Vocabulary - Jan Wk1 2020
content:
Most Common Words: 20 of 500

Note: One of my modest goals for 2020 is to know 500 Russian words by heart. I feel that the best way to accomplish this is to learn around 10 per week and quiz myself throughout the week. So, for this year, I'll post the most common Russian words every week to hold myself accountable.


#

1
иand, though
2

14

16

18

19
кto, for, by
20
уby, with. of
Thoughts on learning through week

As I've been learning Russian for maybe a 4-5 months (sparingly) before starting this blog, I'm somewhat familiar with these words. This is why I'm starting with 20x the first week. Throw these flash cards in front of me and should be no problem.

End Of Week Quiz

title: Setting Up a Blog
content:
Problem

While trying to record my learnings of the Russian Language, it seemed appropriately to log my progress through a blog-like website.

As a hobbyist programmer, I found myself constantly searching for clever ways to solve problems, but then would forget the solutions months later... leaving me frustrated once again on how to get a particular issue resolved.

Solution

While probably unconventional, I decided to combine my efforts of learning a new language and all programming/coding solutions into the same blog in the hopes I can use both as a reference in the future. At the very least I can look back to see progress, find my own documentation and/or sear solutions into memory. At best, I can make my own notes public or any and all to use for their own journey.

All that was left was to find a way to document both my Russian language learning as well as record all learnings in programming & coding . . .

Howabout a Django Blog?
